journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Computation of global trajectories of commercial transport aircraft

article-meta.aff: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Universidad de Sevilla, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Damián Rivas, Departamento de Ingeniería Aeroespacial, Escuela Superior de Ingenieros, Camino de los Descubrimientos, 41092 Sevilla, Spain. Email: drivas@us.es

abstract.p: A trajectory computation tool designed to compute global trajectories (from take off to landing) of commercial transport aircraft is presented. The global trajectory is defined by a general flight intent, considering flight segments usually flown by transport aircraft, including standard airline procedures, and air traffic control regulations. The computation is based on a trajectory computation solver designed for a general aircraft performance model (general drag polar and general engine model); the formulation takes into account wind effects and temperature corrections for a non-standard atmosphere. In the computation of the global trajectory, the top-of-descent point is determined iteratively, using the actual aircraft weight computed along the flight. Global properties such as total fuel consumption and flight time are computed; the influence of the actual take-off weight is analysed, as well as the effects of wind and non-standard temperatures. The computation tool provides a quantitative evaluation of these effects. Results are presented for a medium-range global trajectory and a model of a typical twin-engine, wide-body and, transport aircraft.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The computation of aircraft global trajectories (from take off to landing) is an important problem, both, locally, in the design of efficient trajectories, and, globally, in the management of air traffic. However, in the open literature, most of the computation efforts are not devoted to this global problem. Slattery and Zhao1 synthesise cruise–descent trajectories for air traffic automation. Jackson et al.2 compute descent profiles (formed by five segments) to study the sensitivity of trajectory prediction. Coppenbarger 3 presents a trajectory predictor based on the information provided by the airline flight plan, but only for the climb segment. Coppenbarger et al.4 describe the En-route Descent Advisor, a Center-TRACON Automation System tool that solves the meet-time problem, involving the cruise and descent phases. Global trajectories are considered in the following works. Barman and Erzberger optimise5 fixed-range trajectories for short-haul aircraft, considering the global trajectory as formed by only three flight segments (a very simplified case, although appropriate for complex optimisation problems). Gill and Maddock 6 use predefined strategies to meet time and altitude constraints within the PHARE programme. Gallo et al.7 present a bidimensional trajectory computation infrastructure (simplified by neglecting the acceleration normal to the trajectory), intended to analyse all the BADA 4.0 capabilities.

In this article, a computation tool is presented that computes the global trajectory as actually defined by the flight intent. This tool has been designed to be numerically efficient, in terms of computational cost, to be used for example at the core of trajectory optimisation solvers, which in general, implement iterative procedures that require calling the trajectory computation tool many times. For this reason, the tool is simplified by modelling the heading, the path angle, and the engine rating changes as instantaneous. With these simplifications, the number of flight segments to be computed is greatly reduced.

However, the tool is quite general otherwise. First, it considers a general flight intent, defined by flight segments usually flown by transport aircraft, including standard airline procedures (Standard Instrument Departure, SID and Standard arrival, STAR) and air traffic control (ATC) regulations. Second, the trajectory computation solver is designed for a general aircraft performance model (APM), that is, general drag polar and general engine model. And, third, the formulation takes into account along-track wind effects (crosswind effects are not considered) and temperature corrections for a non-standard atmosphere.

One of the important characteristics of computing global trajectories is that it is a global problem, since boundary conditions are set both at the beginning (departure) and at the end (arrival) of the flight. In practice, this means that the beginning of the descent phase (top of descent, TOD) must be determined iteratively, as it is done in this article using the actual aircraft weight computed along the flight. (In other works, as reported by Williams and Green,8 the global trajectory is computed integrating backwards from the landing runway.)

The trajectory computation tool includes a trajectory computation solver which computes each flight segment (defined by the corresponding flight constraints), with given initial and stopping conditions. This solver is based on the reduction of the system of differential--algebraic equations for each flight segment to a system of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), which is solved by standard numerical procedures.

Results are presented for an APM that models a typical twin-engine, wide-body and, transport aircraft, in the category of the Boeing 767-300ER. An application is made for a flight Madrid–Frankfurt, in which the trajectory is formed by 66 flight segments. Global properties of the trajectory, such as total fuel consumption (trip fuel) and flight time are computed. The influence of the take-off weight is discussed, and the effects of wind and non-standard temperatures are analysed.

sec.title: Global trajectories
sec.p: A global trajectory is composed of flight segments, which in turn define the different flight phases: take-off, climb, cruise, descent, approach, and landing.

In this article, as already indicated, to simplify the trajectory computation tool, heading, path angle and engine rating changes are instantaneously performed. This means that the global trajectory presents discontinuities in heading, path angle and thrust. Also, as a consequence of having instantaneous heading changes, all segments considered in this study are flown in a vertical plane, with constant heading (loxodromic route).

Since there are parts of the global trajectory in which turns are important, such as the approach phase, the relative effect of the assumption of instantaneous heading changes will depend on the length of the trajectory. (In this article, an application is made for a medium-range flight, so as to minimise this effect.)
The global trajectory is defined by horizontal profile and vertical profile, as follows.

sec.title: Horizontal profile
sec.p:
The horizontal profile of the global trajectory describes the horizontal path followed by the aircraft, that is, the path followed on the surface of the Earth (which in this article is considered spherical). This profile is determined by the following elements:
departure airport (with the corresponding SID procedure),
route, and
arrival airport (with the corresponding STAR and approach procedures). The actual path is defined by waypoints, each one given by its geodetic coordinates on the Earth surface (λ, φ). Hence, the nominal horizontal distance between two consecutive waypoints, as well as the total horizontal distance between take-off and landing runways (distances measured along the surface of the Earth), can be computed in advance. The heading angle required to fly from one waypoint to the next can be also computed in advance, from the known geodetic coordinates as shown in section ‘Computation of global trajectories’.

sec.title: Vertical profile
sec.p: These flight segments require some parameters to be properly defined; for instance, the cruise at constant pressure altitude and constant Mach requires these two constant values, which must be defined by the airline, according to ATC regulations and its own operational procedures, so that the flight is optimised, for example according to a given cost index. In this article, all these parameters are supposed given. (The trajectory computation tool presented in this study does not perform any such optimisation, but computes the trajectory for the given parameters.)
The pressure QFE (of both airports) is also needed to fix the corresponding local altimeter settings.
This vertical profile is quite similar to the flight profile used in the experimental flight management system of the PHARE programme.6

sec.title: Equations of motion
sec.p: The model adopted to describe the aircraft motion is that of a point mass with three degrees of freedom, commonly used for trajectory prediction;1 the equations then describe the motion of the aircraft centre of mass, considered as a mass-varying body.
As already stated, the segments to be computed are such that the flight during each segment takes place with constant heading angle, say χ = χA.
In this article, the case of steady horizontal winds, contained in the flight plane, dependent only on altitude is considered.

To solve the problem, T and L must be given (these are the control variables; note that the bank angle is zero), or, equivalently, two conditions (constraints) that close the mathematical problem. The constraints can be control (for example, given engine rating) and/or motion constraints (for example, constant altitude, constant Mach number, etc.). These flight constraints have, in general, the following form (2)f(V,γ,χA,m,ϕ,λ,h,T,L,t)=0 The imposed constraints must be compatible and physically meaningful, that is, they must indeed close the mathematical problem. López et al.11 give a complete description of the different constraints that are meaningful in the ATM context.

Additionally, proper initial conditions must be given, that must be compatible with the flight constraints. The equations of motion (1) plus the constraints (2) form a system of differential–algebraic equations (DAEs).12 The resolution of the DAE systems for the different flight segments is described in section ‘Trajectory computation solver’.

sec.title: Supplementary models
sec.p: The Wind Model provides the function w(h). The particular function used in the applications is described in section ‘Wind effects’. Positive values of w correspond to tailwinds and negative values to headwinds.

The APM provides the required performance characteristics, both aerodynamic and propulsive. The Aerodynamic Model defines the drag polar (3)CD=CD(CL,M) that gives the drag coefficient as a function of the lift coefficient CL and the Mach number M. The lift and drag coefficients are defined by L=1 2ρV2SCL and D=1 2ρV2SCD, respectively, where S is the reference wing surface area. The drag polar must take into account the aerodynamic configuration (clean, high-lift devices, landing gear, spoilers). The model is described in Appendix 3.

The Propulsion Model defines the thrust available and the fuel consumption. In this article, the following model is considered for the fuel consumption (4)m·F=c(V,h)T where c is the specific fuel consumption. The models for the available thrust (for a given engine rating) and the specific fuel consumption can be expressed as (5)T=TRATE(M,h) (6)c=c(M,h) both dependent on Mach number and altitude; they are described in Appendix 3.

In this article, the formulation is made for the general drag polar (equation (3)), the general thrust model for a given engine rating (equation (5)), and the general specific fuel consumption model given by equation (6).

sec.title: Computation of global trajectories
sec.p: To compute the global trajectories, all the flight segments must be computed successively. Each flight segment is defined by the appropriate flight constraints, and its computation starts with the corresponding initial conditions and ends when the appropriate stopping condition is reached.

sec.title: Flight constraints
sec.p:
In this article, all the flight segments considered are defined by means of seven flight constraints, which are analysed as follows.
Constant γ. This constraint sets the value of the state variable γ.
Given TRATE. In cases where the engine rating is given, this constraint defines the thrust law: T = TTO(M, h) for take-off, TMCLB(M, h) for maximum climb or TIDLE(M, h) for idle.
Constant M. When the Mach number is constant, say MA, this constraint defines a known speed law V(h), say V = VM(h), given by (7) V=MAκRaΘ(h)
Constant CAS. When the calibrated air speed (CAS) is constant, say CASA, this constraint defines another known speed law V(h), say V = VC(h), given by13 (8)V=2kRaΘ(h)g[g(1+pSLp(h)g[g(1+k2ρSLpSLCASA2g)1/k-1g]g)k-1g] where k = (κ − 1)/κ and ρSL the reference sea-level density given by the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA) model.
Constant hp. Case of constant pressure altitude, say hpA, that is, a given flight level. This constraint defines a constant altitude, namely, the altitude at which in the ISA+ΔΘ model, one has the same pressure as in the ISA model at pressure altitude hpA. The constant altitude depends on ΔΘ, say hA(ΔΘ). One has the following expressions (according to the atmosphere model described in Appendix 2): for flight in the troposphere (9) thA=ΘSL+ΔΘΘSLhpA and for flight in the stratosphere (10)hA=h*+Θ*ΘISA*(hpA-h*)+Θ*αTlng[Θ*ΘISA*ΘSLΘSL+ΔΘg] where h* is the tropopause altitude and Θ* and ΘISA* the temperature and the ISA temperature at the tropopause, respectively. When the ISA model applies (case ΔΘ = 0), altitude and pressure altitude coincide by definition.
Constant hAGL. Case of constant height above ground level (AGL), say hAGL,A (which applies in segments near the airports, below the transition altitude). This constraint defines a constant altitude as well, which depends on the airport pressure QFE (QFE can be determined, if not given, from the pressure level QNH and the airport elevation). The pressure altitude that corresponds to the airport is (Appendix 2) (11) hp,AP=ΘSLαTg[1-g(QFEpSLg)αTRagg] the pressure altitude that corresponds to the given height AGL is (12) hp,AGL=hAGL,A+hp,AP and the altitude that corresponds to this pressure altitude is given by equation (9).
Constant γg. For the case of constant ground path angle, say γg,A, one has a known aerodynamic path angle law γ = γA(V, h) defined by (13) tanγg,A=VsinγVcosγ+w(h)

sec.title: Initial conditions
sec.p: The initial conditions of the first segment are the initial conditions of the global trajectory, which are given data. For any other segment, the initial conditions are the final conditions of the previous segment, except for the aerodynamic path angle, since this variable may be discontinuous (as discussed in section ‘Global trajectories’). In climb/descent segments, the initial value of γ is estimated using the following approximation, obtained from equations (34) after neglecting the term dγdt(14)L(m,h,γ)-mgcosγ+mdwdhV(h)sin2γ=0

sec.title: Stopping conditions
sec.p:
A total of four stopping conditions are considered in this article, which are analysed now.
Reach a given Mach or CAS. In this case, from the computed values of V and h, the corresponding value of Mach or CAS, defined by equations (7) and (8), must be monitored during the integration, to determine when the event is reached.
Reach a given pressure altitude or height AGL. Now, this condition is equivalent to reaching a given altitude (see section on ‘Flight constraints’), which is a computed variable that must be monitored.
Reach a given horizontal distance (along the Earth surface). The horizontal distance travelled by the aircraft along the surface of the Earth, r, is defined by (15) drdt=RERE+h(Vcosγ+w) Thus, this equation must be integrated along the trajectory, and the variable r must be monitored.
Reach a given waypoint. Reaching a waypoint usually defines a heading change in the horizontal profile. Since the waypoint is defined by its geodetic coordinates (φ, λ), one could use these two variables as the stopping criterion; however, in the trajectory computation tool presented in this article, the horizontal distance travelled from the previous waypoint is used (note that the distances between waypoints are known in advance). Thus, the horizontal distance between two waypoints defined by the nominal coordinates (φ1, λ1) and (φ2, λ2) is given by (except for the trivial case χA = ±π/2, where the route is an Earth parallel) (16) rA=REϕ2-ϕ1cosχA where the heading defined by the two waypoints is given by (17) tanχA=λ2-λ1lntan(π4+ϕ22)-lntan(π4+ϕ12)
Once the waypoint is reached, the new heading to the next waypoint is set for the computation of the next segment.

sec.title: Top of descent
sec.p: As indicated in section ‘Introduction’, the TOD point must be iteratively determined. In this article, the cruise speed reduction (CSR) point is defined as the beginning of the last segment of the cruise phase. This segment is a deceleration at cruise altitude that ends at the TOD point (when the descent Mach number is reached). In the iteration procedure, the CSR point (instead of the TOD point) is iteratively determined, and, then, the TOD point is just the end of the segment.

The iteration task is performed when the aircraft reaches a specified point: the iteration point. In this study, the iteration point is located at a distance of 200 nmi from the destination airport. Once the iteration point is reached, the computed part of the trajectory is saved and the iteration process starts. In this process, the final part of the flight, from the iteration point to the touch down (TD) point, is computed for different approximations of the CSR point until the TD point coincides with the runway location (at each step, the computation starts at the fixed and known iteration point).

sec.title: Trajectory computation solver
sec.p:
The trajectory computation solver computes each flight segment, which requires solving the corresponding DAE system. In the solver presented in this article, the control variables (T, L) are explicitly determined and the DAE system is reduced to an ODE system, that can be solved using standard numerical procedures, such as a Runge–Kutta method. A general analysis of the different flight segments can be found in Miele.14 According to the flight constraints needed in this article to define the global trajectory, there are six types of flight segments to be considered, which are described by the following paragraph. The corresponding ODE system to be solved (obtained from equations (1)) are summarised in Appendix 4.
Initial climb segment. Defined by the two constraints:
constant path angle γ = γA;
take-off rating, that is, known thrust law T = TTO(M, h).
CAS/Mach climb/descent. Defined by the two constraints:
constant Mach M = MA or constant CAS CAS = CASA, that is, known speed law V = VM(h) or V = VC(h); respectively,
given engine rating, maximum climb T = TMCLB(M, h) or idle T = TIDLE(M, h). In general, in this segment one has known functions V(h) and T(M, h).
Horizontal acceleration/deceleration. Defined by the two constraints:
constant height AGL (hAGL,A) or constant pressure altitude (hpA), that is, a constant altitude h = hA;
given engine rating, maximum climb T = TMCLB(M, h) or idle T = TIDLE(M, h), that is, a known function T(M, h).
Cruise. Defined by the two constraints:
constant pressure altitude hp = hpA, that is, a constant altitude h = hA;
constant Mach M = MA, that is, known speed law V = VM(h). In this segment, since h = const, one has V = const, say V = VM(hA) ≡ VA.
Glide path. Defined by the two constraints:
constant ground path angle γg = γg,A (defined by the instrument landing system (ILS)), that is, known path angle law γ = γ(V, h);
constant CAS CAS = CASA (in practice, the approach speed), that is, known speed law V = VC(h). In this segment, since V(h) is given, one has a known path-angle law γ = γ(h).
Take-off/landing. Since only rectilinear segments are considered in this article, flare arcs during take-off and landing are not considered either. Thus, considering horizontal runways, the take-off and landing runs are particular cases of horizontal acceleration/deceleration segments, except that the ground reactions must be added to the dynamic equation of motion (37).

The horizontal reaction force that must be added to the dynamic equation (37) is (18)RTO=-μr(mg-1 2ρAV2SCL,TO) where μr is the rolling friction coefficient (in this article, μr = 0.02), and CL,TO is known. In this segment, the aircraft accelerates from rest to the lift off speed VLOF.

Now, the horizontal reaction force that must be added to dynamic equation (37) is (19)RLD=-μr'(mg-1 2ρAV2SCL,LD) where μr' is now the friction coefficient with brakes applied (in this article, μr' = 0.3), and CL,LD is known. In this segment, the aircraft decelerates from the approach speed Vapp to rest.

sec.title: Application
sec.p: In the following sections, the global trajectory Madrid–Frankfurt is considered. The flight intent and the flight segments are defined in this section, and the computed results obtained for the global trajectory are presented in section ‘Results’. A model of a typical twin-engine, wide-body and, transport aircraft, partly based on B767-300ER data, is used, which is described in Appendix 3. In this application, a nominal take-off weight WTO = 150,000 kg is considered (the effect of WTO is analysed in section ‘Influence of take-off weight’).

sec.title: Departure airport
sec.p: Madrid (LEMD): Runway 36R; elevation hAP = 1942 ft; QFE = 944.1 mbar (value corresponding to the ISA atmosphere; non-standard atmospheres are considered in section ‘Influence of △Θ’).

sec.title: SID
Route
sec.p:
In this article, the route is defined by the 36 waypoints given by the route generator RouteFinder (http://rfinder.asalink.net/free/); they are the following: BAN, LARDA, LATEK, OBUTO, GONUP, TOU, GAI, MAKIL, GONIM, MEN, MEZIN, LATAM, ETREK, LUXAN, ARKOX, LTP, GIPNO, SOPLO, OMASI, MOLUS, SOSAL, TELNO, KORED, KONOL, BERSU, SUREP, DITON, KUDES, SONOM, LADOL, NELLI, KOVAN, SUNEG, ABUKA, RIDSU and ROLIS (the geodetic coordinates of these points are also given by the route generator RouteFinder).. The route is represented in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Horizontal profile.

sec.title: Arrival airport
sec.p: Frankfurt (EDDF): Runway 25R; elevation hAP = 364 ft; QFE = 1000.0 mbar (value corresponding to the ISA atmosphere; non-standard atmospheres are considered in section ‘Influence of △Θ’).

sec.title: Standard arrival STAR
Instrument approach
sec.p: After MTR (IAF), an additional waypoint (WPT 43) is needed, in order to follow the runway course. The following geodetic coordinates are taken for this last waypoint: N 50° 07′ 30″ and E 08° 55′ 45″.

sec.title: Vertical profile
sec.p: It has been decided to cruise at a fixed altitude. Nevertheless, a stepped cruise climb could be also considered, to approximate the optimal cruise climb, as done in operational practice, just by adding a climb segment for each step.

sec.title: Flight segments
sec.p:
The flight Madrid–Frankfurt is composed of a total of 66 segments, which are defined in Table 1. In this table, the following data are presented: constraints defining the segment, estimated initial condition for γ (in segments where this is not the final value of the previous segment), stopping condition and additional parameters required to compute the segment (χA, ΔCD,…). Other parameters could be the wind speed and ΔΘ during the segment, but in Table 1, the case of no wind and ISA atmosphere is considered (wind effects are analysed in section ‘Wind effects’ and non-standard atmospheres in section ‘Influence of △Θ’. Note that, for conciseness purposes, segments 17–49 are not included in the table, since they correspond to the cruise phase and the only parameters that change are χA and the corresponding stopping condition. Table 1.
Flight segments.
Segment numbers Constraint 1 Constraint 2 Initial condition γ (degrees) Stopping condition Parameters
χA (degrees) ΔCD
1 TAKE-OFF 0.00 CAS = 146.4 kt 360.00 0.028
2 TO γ = 3° 3.00 CAS = 161.4 kt 360.00 0.028
3 TO CAS = 161.4 kt 9.75 hAGL = 1500 ft 360.00 0.010

10 MCLB CAS = 290.0 kt 7.05 WPT 2 39.45 0

15 M = 0.80 hp = 33,000 ft – WPT 4 356.16 0
16 M = 0.80 hp = 33,000 ft – WPT 5 49.50 0
⋮ ⋮ ⋮ ⋮ ⋮ ⋮ ⋮
50 M = 0.80 hp = 33,000 ft – CSR 335.53 0
51 IDLE hp = 33,000 ft – M = 0.78 335.53 0
52 IDLE M = 0.78 −3.28 WPT 38 335.53 0

54 IDLE CAS = 290.0 kt −2.34 WPT 39 328.53 0
55 IDLE CAS = 290.0 kt – WPT 40 129.23 0
56 IDLE CAS = 290.0 kt – hp = 10,000 ft 124.59 0
57 IDLE hp = 10,000 ft 0.00 CAS = 250.0 kt 124.59 0
58 IDLE CAS = 250.0 kt −2.45 WPT 41 124.59 0

61 IDLE hAGL = 4000 ft 0.00 CAS = 175.5 kt 161.16 0

66 LANDING 0.00 CAS = 0 kt 250.00 0.079
CAS: calibrated air speed; MCLB: maximum climb engine rating; WPT: waypoint; CSR: cruise speed reduction; ILS: instrument landing system.

After take-off, the landing gear is retracted at the end of segment 2 (at a speed CAS = 161.4 kt), and the flaps (15°) at the end of segment 6 (at CAS = 181.2 kt). Before landing, the flaps are extended (25°) at the beginning of segment 62 (at CAS = 175.5 kt), and they are extended further (30°) along with the landing gear at the beginning of segment 64 (at CAS = 125.7 kt). The corresponding changes in the drag polar appear in the last column of Table 1. Segment 50 is stopped by the condition of reaching the CSR point, which is iteratively obtained, and segment 64 by the condition of intercepting the glide path. The TOD point is the end of segment 51.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The global trajectory Madrid–Frankfurt is now computed, using the trajectory computation solver presented in section ‘Trajectory computation solver’. The equations defining each flight segment are solved using Matlab's ODE solvers.

sec.title: Global trajectory
sec.p:
In this section, the global trajectory is computed for the nominal take-off weight WTO = 150,000 kg, with no wind and ISA atmosphere. The horizontal profile is depicted in Figure 1, and the vertical profile in Figure 2, where the marks correspond to the different waypoints. Figure 2.
Vertical profile. TOD: top of descent; TOC: top of climb.

The main global results of the trajectory, fuel consumption (mF) and flight time (tf) are listed in Table 2 (also shown are results for take-off weights varying −20 per cent and +20 per cent, 120,000 and 180,000 kg, respectively). Other parameters listed are the following points: top of climb (distance from lift off), top of descent (distance to TD), and CSR (distance to TD). Table 2.
Global parameters.
WTO (kg) mF (kg) tf (s) TOC (nmi) CSR (nmi) TOD (nmi)
120 000 8442.5 8262.1 50.37 128.31 126.90
150,000 10,220.4 8262.9 69.72 133.81 132.35
180,000 12,580.6 8277.7 97.65 133.65 132.24
TOD: top of descent; CSR: cruise speed reduction; TOC: top of climb.

sec.title: Influence of take-off weight
sec.p: As indicated by Coppenbarger,3 the take-off weight can vary largely from a mean value (for instance, in a range as wide as −23 per cent to +37 per cent for B757 aircraft). The effect of WTO on the global trajectory is analysed.

The effect on the vertical profile is presented in Figure 3, for the climb and descent phases. As WTO increases, the horizontal distance travelled during climb sharply increases. The variation of the TOC point with WTO is shown in Figure 4. As listed in Table 2, the TOC point goes from 50.4 nmi for WTO = 120,000 kg to 97.7 nmi for WTO = 180,000 kg (it almost doubles); see also Figure 3. The effect of WTO on the CRS and TOD points is much weaker, as shown in Figures 3 and 4. Figure 3.
Effect of take-off weight on the vertical profile (climb and descent).
Figure 4.
Effect of take-off weight on TOD, CSR, and top of climb. TOD: top of descent; CSR: cruise speed reduction; TOC: top of climb.

The fuel consumption is very sensitive to changes in WTO, as shown in Figure 5. As listed in Table 2, mF goes from 8442.5 kg for WTO = 120,000 to 125 80.6 kg for WTO = 180,000 kg (a difference of about 4138 kg of fuel, with respect to a nominal fuel consumption of 10 220.4 kg). Figure 5.
Effect of take-off weight on fuel consumption and flight time.

The effect of WTO on the flight time is, however, very weak, as shown in Figure 5 and Table 2. When WTO increases from 120,000 to 180,000 kg, tf increases from 8262 to 8278 s (a difference of just 16 s, with respect to a nominal flight time of 8263 s).

In conclusion, the effects of WTO on the climb vertical profile and the global fuel consumption are quite strong, whereas the effects on the descent vertical profile and the global flight time are very weak. As indicated by Coppenbarger,3 in the analysis of climb trajectories, ATM decision support tools must consider the actual take-off weight (ATOW) (accurately defined), rather than applying an average WTO to all aircraft of a given type, especially with regard to the important issue of fuel consumption, as it has been shown in this section.

sec.title: Wind effects
sec.p: The winds considered in this section are defined by a constant direction (φw) on the whole flight, and an altitude-dependent modulus (Vw(h)) given by the following function16 (20)Vw=v0+40 33,000h where v0 and Vw are expressed in knots and h in feet. In the application, two cases of wind direction are considered: NE (φw = 45°) and SW (φw = 225°), giving headwinds and tailwinds, respectively, in most part of the flight, and the wind speed at sea level, v0, ranges from 0 to 30 kt. The take-off weight, in this section, is the nominal value WTO = 150,000 kg, and the atmosphere model is ISA.

To maintain the segment course in the presence of crosswinds, the aircraft heading must be changed. These heading changes (which affect the ground speed) are not taken into account in this study. The effects of this simplification will depend on the strength of the crosswinds. (In this article, an application is made for winds roughly aligned with the overall flight direction, so as to minimize this effect.)

In each flight segment, the component of the wind velocity contained in the plane of flight (w in equation (1)) must be determined, which depends on the segment heading, χA, as well as on the wind direction, φw. Thus, one has (21)w(h)=-Vw(h)cos(χA-ϕw)

The effect of wind on the vertical profile is shown in Figure 6, for the climb and descent phases. In this figure, profiles for v0 = 0, 10, 20, and 30 kt are shown for each wind direction, along with the nominal profile for the case of no wind. One can see that headwinds, case φw = 45° (NE), decrease the TOC and TOD, and tailwinds, case φw = 225° (SW), increase them. Some numerical results are given in Table 3. For the case of v0 = 30 kt, the difference in TOC between headwind and tailwind is 21.6 nmi, and the difference in TOD, in the same case, is 10.4 nmi. Table 3.
Wind effect on global parameters.
v0 (kt) mF (kg) tf (s) TOC (nmi) TOD (nmi)
No wind 10,220.4 8262.9 69.72 132.35
0 NE 10,824.6 8798.6 64.16 129.64
10 NE 10,961.9 8937.5 62.43 128.77
20 NE 11,114.5 9086.9 60.67 127.87
30 NE 11,280.7 9246.5 58.90 126.91
0 SW 9710.7 7808.6 75.25 135.08
10 SW 9640.3 7722.5 76.95 135.86
20 SW 9585.6 7645.2 78.71 136.60
30 SW 9548.6 7577.9 80.47 137.30
TOC: top of climb; TOD: top of descent.
Figure 6.
Wind effect on the vertical profile (climb and descent).

The fuel consumption and flight time are shown in Figure 7 as a function of v0, for each wind direction, along with the result for the case of no wind. As expected, both global parameters increase with headwinds (NE) and decrease with tailwinds (SW). Some numerical results are given in Table 3. For the case of v0 = 30 kt, the difference between headwind and tailwind is as large as 1732 kg in fuel consumption and 1669 s (almost 28 min) in flight time. Figure 7.
Wind effect on fuel consumption and flight time.
As shown, wind effects can be very large. The computation tool developed in this article allows one to quantify these effects (provided the wind is known).

sec.title: Influence of ΔΘ
sec.p: The effect of non-standard days on the global trajectory is analysed in this section. The take-off weight is the nominal value WTO = 150,000 kg, and the case of no wind is considered. To simplify the analysis, a constant value of ΔΘ is taken for the whole flight.

The effect of ΔΘ on the vertical profile is shown in Figure 8, for the climb and descent phases. In this figure, profiles for ΔΘ = −20, −10, 0, 10, and 20 K are shown (the nominal profile for the ISA model corresponds to ΔΘ = 0). One can see that hot days increase the TOC and TOD, and cold days decrease them (notice the change in cruise altitude corresponding to the given cruise pressure altitude). Some numerical results are given in Table 4. For the cases of ΔΘ = −20 and 20 K, the difference in TOC between hot and cold days is 26.0 nmi, and the difference in TOD, in the same cases, is 17.4 nmi. Table 4.
Effect of ΔΘ on global parameters.
ΔΘ (K) mF (kg) tf (s) TOC (nmi) TOD (nmi)
−20 10,182.6 8504.8 57.66 123.64
−10 10,200.9 8379.9 63.47 128.00
0 10,220.4 8262.9 69.72 132.35
10 10,241.1 8153.1 76.45 136.69
20 10,263.1 8049.9 83.69 141.03
TOC: top of climb; TOD: top of descent.
Figure 8.
Effect of ΔΘ on the vertical profile (climb and descent).

The fuel consumption and flight time are shown in Figure 9 as a function of ΔΘ. Flight time decreases for hot days and increases for cold days (notice that, since the cruise Mach number is constant, the cruise airspeed increases in hot days and decreases in cold days). The influence of ΔΘ on fuel consumption is very small, increasing for hot days and decreasing for cold days. Some numerical results are given in Table 4. For the cases of ΔΘ = −20 and 20 K, the difference between hot and cold days is just 80.5 kg (increase) in fuel consumption and 455 s (decrease) in flight time. This effect is not as important as wind effects however, it must be taken into account. Figure 9.
Effect of ΔΘ on fuel consumption and flight time.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, a trajectory computation tool has been presented and designed to compute the global trajectories in quite general scenarios, for commercial transport aircraft, including actual flight intents, a general APM, wind, and a non-standard atmosphere. The tool is based on a kinetic modelling approach, which is flexible and transparent. To reduce the computational cost, some simplifications have been made, although the tool is robust enough to be useful in the computation of global properties such as total fuel consumption and flight time, and in quantifying the effects of wind and non-standard days on them.

As an application, a flight Madrid–Frankfurt has been analysed. The results show the strong effect of take-off weight on the climb vertical profile and on the global fuel consumption, which leads to the conclusion that the weight sensitivity is high and, therefore, the actual take-off weight (ATOW) must be accurately defined in order to have a reliable computed trajectory. Wind effects have been shown to be quite important; given a known wind, the trajectory computation tool allows one to quantify these effects. The effects of a non-standard atmosphere on the global trajectory have been shown to be relatively small, as compared to the other effects analysed.

To assess the accuracy of the tool, comparison with real flight data should be made, which would require recording the following data from the flight: ATOW, final weight, flight time, atmospheric temperature, wind profile, aerodynamic configuration along the trajectory and actual path followed by the aircraft as defined by ATC. With this information, once the trajectory is modelled, the final weight and flight time can be computed and compared with the real ones. If it is considered that the real data have no errors, then the differences can be analysed and attributed to inaccuracies in the trajectory modelling (e.g. definition of segments or assumptions in the equations of motion), inaccuracies in the aerodynamic and propulsive models or inaccuracies in the atmosphere model.

An application foreseen for the tool is the optimisation of global trajectories (that is, optimisation of the main parameters that define them, for instance, fuel consumption and flight time) in terms of key operational parameters, such as the climb/descent speeds, the cruise altitude, and so on. Clearly, this tool can be also applied in the optimisation of parts of the trajectory, such as the cruise and the descent; in particular, in the optimisation of continuous descent approaches, in which the start of the approach is not known in advance, but must be iteratively determined. This study is under way.
Another future application is the analysis of the sensitivity of trajectory prediction to uncertainties in input parameters such as weight, wind, and speed profile, among others.

In other applications, such as the analysis of convergent traffic in the TMA, including the problem of conflict detection and resolution, where the turns are an important part of the trajectory, a different tool which includes turning segments should be used to compute the trajectories with the required accuracy. These segments add new levels of complexity, with variations in wind direction along the path, and additional iterative loops. Also, in the computation of short-range trajectories, in which the relative effect of turning segments can be important, the use of such an advanced tool is required. The development of such a tool is left for future study. This advanced tool will also take into account the effects of crosswinds.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Atmosphere model
sec.p: The atmosphere model considers a temperature deviation ΔΘ with respect to the ISA model. It is a simple model defined by a constant ΔΘ value for the whole atmosphere layer analysed (troposphere and the first part of the stratosphere), and by a constant altitude for the tropopause. This model establishes the following relationships of air temperature, pressure, and density with altitude.

Troposphere. (22)Θ=ΘSL+ΔΘ-αTh,p=pSLg(1-αThΘSL+ΔΘg)gRaαT (23)ρ=ρSLg(1-αThΘSL+ΔΘg)gRaαT-1ΘSLΘSL+ΔΘ Stratosphere. (24)Θ=Θ*,p=p*expg(-g(h-h*)RaΘ*g),ρ=ρ*expg(-g(h-h*)RaΘ*g) where at sea level ΘSL = 288.15 K, pSL = 101.325 kN/m2, and ρSL = 1.225 kg/m3; at the tropopause Θ*, p*, and ρ* follow from the expressions above for the troposphere particularised for the tropopause altitude h* = 11,000 m; and αT = 6.5 10−3 K/m.

sec.title: Aircraft model
sec.p: The aircraft model used in the computations, partly based on B767-300ER data, is described as follows. The model has wing surface area 283.3 m2 and maximum take-off weight 1,832,666 N.

The drag polar defined by Cavcar and Cavcar 17 is considered; it is given by (25)CD=g(CD0,i+∑j=15k0jKjg(Mg)g)+g(CD1,i+∑j=15k1jKjg(Mg)g)CL +g(CD2,i+∑j=15k2jKjg(Mg)g)CL2 where (26)Kg(Mg)=g(M-0.4g)21-M2 The incompressible drag polar coefficients are CD0i = 0.01322, and CD1i = –0.00610 and CD2i = 0.06000, and the compressible coefficients are given in Table 5. This polar is valid for M ⩾ 0.4; for M ⩽ 0.4, the incompressible drag polar applies (obtained by setting K = 0 in equation (25)). Table 5.
Compressible drag-polar coefficients for the model aircraft.
j12345
k0j 0.0067 −0.1861 2.2420 −6.4350 6.3428
k1j 0.0962 −0.7602 −1.2870 3.7925 −2.7672
k2j −0.1317 1.3427 −1.2839 5.0164 0.0000

For non-clean configurations, the following CD increments are considered: ΔCD = 0.010, 0.021, and 0.043 for flaps deflections 15°, 25°, and 30°, ΔCD = 0.018 for the landing gear and ΔCD = 0.018 for the spoilers. For the take-off and landing runs, the values of lift coefficient considered are CL,TO = 1.4 and CL,LD = 1.7.

For the available thrust, the following general model is considered18 (27)T=WTOδCT(M,Nc) where WTO is the reference take-off weight, δ = p/pSL the pressure ratio and CT the thrust coefficient, which in general is a function of the Mach number and the engine control parameter, Nc. For a given engine rating (take-off, maximum climb or idle), the control parameter is a function of Mach number and altitude (Nc(M, h)); therefore, one can also write the model as T = TRATE(M, h), that is, thrust dependent both on Mach number and altitude.

Although different functional dependencies should be used for the various engine ratings, in this article, for simplicity, the following single model is considered for the thrust coefficient5,19) (28)90%CT=TSL,RATEWTO(1+κ-1 2M2)κκ-1(1-0.49M)1θ where TSL,RATE is the thrust at sea level and for M = 0 for the given engine rating, having the following values for the engine of the model aircraft: TSL,TO = 5.15 × 105 N, TSL,MCLB = 4.89 × 105 N, and TSL,IDLE = 0.073 × 105 N.

For the specific fuel consumption, the following general model is considered18 (29)c=aSLθLHCC(M) where aSL=κRaΘSL the speed of sound at sea level, θ = Θ/ΘSL the temperature ratio, LH the fuel latent heat and CC the specific fuel consumption coefficient.

For the specific fuel consumption coefficient, the linear model defined by Mattingly et al.19 (and approximately depicted by Miele14) is considered; it is given by (30)CC=cSLLHaSLg(1.0+1.2Mg) where cSL is the specific fuel consumption at sea level and for M = 0, whose value for the engine of the model aircraft is cSL = 9.01 × 10−6 kg/(s N). For the fuel latent heat, one has LH = 43 × 106 J/kg. In general, CC is a function of M and the thrust coefficient CT however, the dependence of CC with CT is in practice very weak and can be neglected.18

sec.title: Initial climb segment
sec.p: The equations of motion (1) reduce to (31)mdVdt=TTO(M,h)-1 2ρV2SCD(M,CL) -mg(g+V dw dhcosγAg)sinγAdm dt=-c(M,h)TTO(M,h)(RE+h)dϕdt=(VcosγA+w)cosχA(RE+h)cosϕdλdt=(VcosγA+w)sinχAdh dt=VsinγA where the lift coefficient CL(V, h, m) is given by (32)CL=2L(V,h,m)ρV2S with (33)L=mgcosγA-mdwdhVsin2γA

sec.title: CAS/Mach climb/descent
sec.p: The equations of motion (1) reduce to (34)mV(h)dγdt=L(m,h,γ)-mgcosγ+mdwdhV(h)sin2γdmdt=-c(M,h)T(M,h)(RE+h)dϕdt=(V(h)cosγ+w)cosχA(RE+h)cosϕdλdt=(V(h)cosγ+w)sinχAdhdt=V(h)sinγ where the lift L(m, h, γ) is given by (35)L=1 2ρV2(h)SCL(m,h,γ) and the lift coefficient CL(m, h, γ) is the solution of (36)1 2ρV2(h)SCD(M,CL)= T(M,h)-mg[g+V(h)g(dV dh+dw dhcosγg)g]sinγ which depends on the drag polar model considered.

sec.title: Horizontal acceleration/deceleration
sec.p: The equations of motion (1) reduce to (37)mdVdt=T(M,hA)-1 2ρAV2SCD(M,CL)dmdt=-c(M,hA)T(M,hA)(RE+hA)dϕdt=(V+w)cosχA(RE+hA)cosϕdλdt=(V+w)sinχA where the lift coefficient CL(V, m) is given by (38)CL=2mgρAV2S
In this segment, one has L = mg and γ = 0.

sec.title: Cruise
sec.p: Equation (1) reduce to (39)dmdt=-c(MA,hA)T(m)(RE+hA)dϕdt=(VA+w)cosχA(RE+hA)cosϕdλdt=(VA+w)sinχA where the required thrust T(m) is given by (40)T=1 2ρAVA2SCD(MA,CL) with (41)CL=2mgρAVA2S
In this segment, one has L = mg and γ = 0.

sec.title: Glide path
sec.p: Equations (1) reduce to (42)dmdt=-c(M,h)T(h,m)(RE+h)dϕdt=(VC(h)cosγ(h)+w)cosχA(RE+h)cosϕdλdt=(VC(h)cosγ(h)+w)sinχAdhdt=VC(h)sinγ(h) where the required thrust T(h, m) is given by (43)T=1 2ρVC2(h)SCD(M,CL) +mg[g+VC(h)g(dVCdh+dw dhcosγ(h)g)g]sinγ(h) with (44)CL=2L(h,m)ρVC2(h)S and (45)L=mgcosγ(h)+mVC(h) ×sinγ(h)g[VC(h)dγdh-dw dhsinγ(h)g]
